Engineer Rick Mastracchio of NASA near the town of Zhezkazgan, Kazakhstan2930 Jupiter's Great Red Spot Viewed by Voyager I3030 Chandra Observatory Sees a Heart in the Darkness“But the question that has been persisting is where inside Jupiter, for example, this transformation to a metallic state would occur.”In their study, published in the journal Science, Dr McWilliams and his colleagues documented this process in unprecedented detail.They found that the transition from transparent to opaque material took place as the hydrogen was squeezed under about 1.5 million times normal atmospheric pressure, and the metallic state arrived as this came closer to 2 million times.“To build better models of potential exoplanetary architecture, this transition between gas and metallic liquid hydrogen must be demonstrated and understood,” explained Dr Alexander Goncharov from the Carnegie Institution for Science.Besides probing the inner workings of these distant planets, subjecting hydrogen to such intense treatments has a role to play closer to home in the development of new energy sources.The ultimate goal of the National Ignition Facility, where the research took place, is to use lasers to compress hydrogen fuel with the goal of inducing nuclear fusion reactions.Fusion energy is the opposite of fission energy – the type generated in nuclear power stations – and scientists have been trying to find a way to harness it for decades.Unlike fission, which produces dangerous radioactive waste, fusion is expected to come with minimal safety concerns.The main models for nuclear fusion are stars, and attempts to produce a workable fusion-based power source are in part attempts to emulate them. Dr McWilliams said their research adds another piece to this on-going puzzle.“We are mapping the path hydrogen takes from a gas to the conditions we might see in the centre of Jupiter, and ultimately this will tell us how we reach conditions in the centre of stars – which are even more extreme than those we studied,” he explained.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: social media influencers celebrities cma watchdog investigation commercial content
story: Created with Sketch.Watchdog says some posts don't clearly state they are paid for by a brandClick to followThe Independent OnlineThe Advertising Standards Authority has intervened in a number of cases were rules have been breached, including one post by Millie MackintoshSocial media stars promoting goods on Instagram, Snapchat and other social media platforms are being probed by the competition regulator over concerns that paid advertisements are not being properly declared.The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) launched an investigation on Tuesday into the labelling of online endorsements.Some celebrities and influencers have a considerable amount of commercial power thanks to millions of followers who watch their channels to see where they go on holiday, what they wear, which products they use, the books they read and more.This makes online endorsements from celebrities and influencers valuable to brands trying to reach target audiences and boost sales.But the watchdog fears some influencers are flouting consumer protection law which requires that any reward received for an endorsement, is made clear.If celebrities do not label their posts properly, fans or followers may be led to believe that an endorsement represents the star’s own view, rather than a paid-for promotion, the CMA&nbspsaid.They are then more likely to place trust in that product than they would otherwise have been, the watchdog said, as they think it has been recommended by someone they admire.The five biggest fashion influencers from this year’s Love IslandThis LA mural is reserved for social media influencersLuxury hotel overwhelmed by influencers asking for free roomsFitness influencer criticised for promoting 'dangerous' diet pillsThe CMA investigation will seek to find whether and to what extent people are being misled by social media posts.Several stars&nbsphave faced action from the Advertising Standards Authority over paid-for posts which were not properly labelled.An ad for Britivic's&nbspJ20&nbspappearing on Made in Chelsea star Millie Mackintosh's Instagram account was banned by the ASA in 2015 while Celebrity Big Brother contestant Stephanie Davis had her post featuring a vitamin company was banned earlier this year.George Lusty, the CMA’s Senior director for consumer&nbspprotection, said: Social media stars can have a big influence on what their followers do and buy.If people see clothes, cosmetics, a car, or a holiday being plugged by someone they admire, they might be swayed into buying it.So, it’s really important they are clearly told whether a celebrity is promoting a product because they have bought it themselves, or because they have been paid or thanked in some way by the brand.The&nbspCMA&nbsphas written to a range of celebrities and social media influencers to gather more information about the deals they have with brands.If it finds practices that break consumer protection law, it can take enforcement action.Enter story: Created with Sketch.Exclusive: Major union joins the campaign as The Independent also teams up with People's Vote&nbspfor mass march in LondonClick to followIndy PoliticsBritish steelworkers join The Independent's campaign for a Final Say referendum on BrexitBritish steelworkers today throw their weight behind The Independent’s campaign for a Final Say referendum on Brexit. &nbspThe Community union – representing some 30,000 workers in total – calls on Theresa May to “do the right thing” and allow the British public to determine their own future.In a further significant development in the drive for a new referendum, The Independent and the People’s Vote campaign are joining forces for a mass march through central London later this year.The alliance will see the two organisations mobilise activists and media across the country to capture the growing tide of opinion that a further referendum on Brexit must be held.Polls show fast increasing support for the idea amid deepening Tory isions, doubts that Ms May can secure parliamentary backing for her plans and meagre public support for her approach.Relations between UK and EU negotiators have also descended into a new state of paranoia this week, with Brussels not denying reports that its officials believe they are being bugged by British spies.It is against this backdrop that Community general secretary Roy Rickhuss writes exclusively for The Independent, saying: “In June 2016, the British public gave our government a mandate to go and negotiate a withdrawal from the European Union.“Exactly what that looked like was unclear, but Theresa May told us she would go in and negotiate a deal that is in the best interests of British workers and their families.“It now seems that such a deal is unachievable or may not exist. That is why my trade union, Community, is backing&nbspThe Independent’s Final Say&nbspcampaign, to secure a people’s vote on the final deal.”Contribute to the march of a generationAt the last People’s Vote March in June, well over 100,000 people marched on parliament.Community’s roots are in textile manufacturing and the steel industry – pushed to the brink of collapse in recent years as much larger economies such as China distort international markets.In 2018 the industry has faced new pressure in particular from steel tariffs imposed by Donald Trump’s US administration, which Brexiteers are relying on for a favourable future trade deal.Community also supports prison and justice workers, logistics, finance, politics and public affairs staff, the charity and freelance sectors and is affiliated to the Labour&nbspParty.Mr Rickhuss highlighted London School of Economics data concluding Brexit was already costing the average UK household more than £404 a year by June 2017.People's title: ilhan omar wins minnesota democratic primary victory speech watch
story: Created with Sketch.'In my last race, I talked about what my win would have meant for that eight-year-old girl in that refugee camp,' she tells crowdClick to followThe Independent USIlhan Omar, who is likely to become the first Somali-American elected to US Congress, made history on Tuesday by winning a seat in Minnesota’s 5th Congressional District.The politician garnered national attention just two years ago after becoming the first Somali American elected to a state legislature in Minnesota - unseating a 22-term Democratic incumbent.In my last race, I talked about what my win would have meant for that eight-year-old girl in that refugee camp,” she told a crowd of supporters after her win.&nbspJahana Hayes could be Connecticut's first black Democrat in CongressTransgender candidate Christine Hallquist makes history in VermontAlexandria Ocasio-Cortez supports Kaniela Ing in Hawaii primaries“And today, today, I still think about her and I think about the kind of hope and optimism all of those eight-year-olds around the country and around the world get from seeing your beautiful faces elect and believe in someone like me.“So I humbly thank you. I congratulate you and I ask you, lets continue to celebrate and bring our joy and hope to the campaign trail tomorrow.”Ms Omar’s family fled Somalia when she was just eight years old as civil war ripped apart the country. They spent four years in a camp in Mombasa, Kenya, with tens of thousands of other refugees.&nbspThe 36-year-old, who is the youngest of seven children, and her family emigrated to America when she was 12 years old. They settled in Minneapolis where she&nbsplearnt English by watching American TV.The mother-of-three also referenced her eight-year-old self when becoming the first Somali-American lawmaker in the US in 2016.This really was a victory for that eight-year-old in that refugee camp, she said. This was a victory for the young woman being forced into child marriage. This was a victory for every person that's been told they have limits on their dreams.Minnesota is home to the biggest population of Somalis outside Somalia and Minneapolis has a neighbourhood nicknamed “Little Mogadishu.”&nbspMs Omar won in Minneapolis and surrounding suburbs – a famously left-leaning district. Her primary victory is expected to lead to a win in the November midterm elections and take her to Congress. She will face Republican candidate Jennifer Zeilinski at the election.&nbspTonight, we are celebrating because we engaged and empowered our community and we won, Ms Omar said in a statement.Our campaign staff, our volunteers, and the people of the Fifth Congressional District are the inspiration we need to get up every day and fight for a democracy that guarantees a more just and equitable society.Ms Omar and Rashida Tlaib - a Palestinian American who won a Detroit-area Democratic primary in Michigan last week and is running unopposed in November - are now in the position to become the first two Muslim women to serve in Congress.I can't wait to walk onto the floor of United States Congress hand in hand with you. So incredibly proud of you.” Ms Tlaib tweeted.A record number of Muslims - at least 90 – have run for political office in the 2018 midterm elections.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Created with Sketch.Russian president expresses hope leaders will discuss 'bilateral relations and important matters'Click to followThe Independent OnlineVladimir Putin ready to meet Kim Jong-un to discuss 'urgent issues', says North Korean state mediaThe Russian&nbsppresident congratulated Mr Kim in a telegram to mark&nbspNorth Korea’s national liberation day,&nbspwhich commemorates&nbspthe end of the Second World War and the north’s liberation from Japanese colonial rule, the KCNA news agency reported.“I affirm that I am ready to meet you at an early date to discuss urgent issues of bilateral relations and important matters of the region,” Mr Putin said in the message, without offering a specific date.North and South Korean leaders announce Pyongyang summitNorth Korea hits out at US sanctions and demands to denucleariseNorth Korea has not stopped nuclear weapons programme, UN saysTrump thanks Kim Jong-un for ‘nice letter’ and ‘kind actions’He also expressed hope&nbspthe countries would “continue to develop cooperation for mutual benefits including the realisation of the tripartite project” which would also involve South Korea.Speaking to journalists on Wednesday, the Kremlin’s spokesman, Dmitry&nbspPeskov, confirmed Mr Putin had sent the telegram in which he “stressed his desire and readiness to establish a dialogue,” Channel NewsAsia reported.In June, Mr Putin invited Mr Kim and South Korea’s president, Moon Jae-in, to an economic forum due to take place in Vlaostok next month. It is unclear whether the North Korean leader responded.When Mr Peskov was asked whether the two leaders could meet in Vlaostok, he said the economic forum is&nbsp”open for all the leaders of the region” but said Moscow has “so far” received no confirmation&nbspfrom Pyongyang to indicate Mr Kim&nbspwill attend.Mr Kim also sent a message to Mr Putin, KCNA reported, noting the “valuable tradition” as they “struggled shoulder to shoulder against the common enemy in the arduous anti-Japanese war”, which it said provided the “strong roots” for their diplomatic relations.It was unclear if the message came before or after Mr Putin’s invitation.It comes as North Korea marked its liberation from Japanese rule&nbspwith relatively low-key celebrations.A group of war veterans from the former Soviet Union participated and thousands of people cheered their football team to victory over a South Korean squad in the opening match of an under-15 youth tournament in Pyongyang, which featured players from several countries.People also streamed to statues of the country’s leaders or other monuments to observe the anniversary, as is customary.Escape from North KoreaA hat belonging to Jeong Min-woo in Seoul. Min-woo is from Hyesan, on the border with China. He was a commissioned officer in the Korean People's Army, and left in his uniform. South Korean intelligence confiscated it, but he persuaded his North Korean military contacts to send him a new one.Jeong Min-woo, 29, poses for a photograph in SeoulKang, 28, who wanted to be identified only by her surname, poses for a photograph in Seoul. The parents of Kang sent out a coat across the Chinese border after she reached the South in 2010. I didn't ask my mother to send me this coat, said Kang. story: Created with Sketch.Her interview was cut short when she placed her hand over her heartClick to followThe Independent OnlineFarah Alhajeh had tried to avoid any upset in the interview by greeting both men and women by placing her hand over her heart (file image)A Swedish&nbspMuslim&nbspwoman whose job interview was terminated when she refused to shake hands with a man has won compensation.Farah Alhajeh, 24, was applying for a job as an interpreter in her hometown of Uppsala&nbspwhen, for religious reasons, she placed her hand over her heart instead of shaking the hand of her male interviewer.In the first judgement of its kind, the Swedish labour court ruled the company had discriminated against her.Muslim Tory peer ‘facing politically motivated’ attacks from own party‘Letterbox’ insults against Muslims spike in wake of Johnson commentsThe company had argued her actions contravened their requirement for staff to treat men and women equally.Ms Alhajeh&nbspwould have provided interpretation services via telephone or video,&nbspThe Local reported, and would not have had to meet customers face-to-face.The office of Sweden’s discrimination ombudsman argued she had tried to avoid any upset in the interview by greeting both men and women by placing her hand over her heart.The company was ordered to pay 40,000 kronor (£3,400) in compensation.World news in picturesA man wades through flooded water in Kochi, Kerala state, India. According to reports, the region is on a high alert with schools and offices been closed due to the rising water levels of Periyar river after the gates of the Idukki reservoir were opened. title: brexit news motorists car tyre labels eu regulations
story: EU chiefs want to toughen regulations to ensure that all new tyres fitted to vehicles on public roads are printed with information about their fuel efficiency, safety and noise standards.And even though the UK is due to quit the EU next year, British drivers could still be affected by the change - expected in 2020 if agreed by MEPs - because Brussels regulations are due to remain in force after Brexit under Theresa May's plans.Campaigners from the Brexit-backing grassroots pressure group Get Britain Out claimed the move could add up to &pound15 to the price of a tyre for a middle-range family saloon through increased production and design costs.Jayne Adye, director of Get Britain Out, said: &ldquoThis proposed EU regulation demonstrates how out of touch the European Commission is with the real world.Motorists could be penalised by the EU regulations   (Image: NC)Whilst it may look good on paper over in Brussels, this regulation would harm British motorists and farmers burdened with extra costs.&ldquoThere are many pieces of legislation, such as this one, which are set to come into force before December 2020 and the end of the Brexit transition period.It is imperative we leave as soon as possible to avoid such red tape entering our statute book.She added: &ldquoThe Commission has no intention of stopping with this piece of regulation.                Cyclists should face same punishment as drivers, says motoring lawyer                 Car tax changes could see YOU charged based on the amount of miles ...The revised energy labels for tyres strengthen the requirements on fuel efficiency, noise and safety, and will apply to tyres on all road-using vehicles including cars, vans and lorries.EU officials say the new labelling will be beneficial for the environment by increasing fuel efficiency and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.&nbsp It will lead to CO2 savings equivalent of removing almost four million passenger cars from EU roads per year by 2030, according to Brussels estimates.The RAC last night backed the new labelling system. RAC spokesman Simon Williams said: &ldquoStrengthening the tyre labelling regulations is good news for UK motorists and road safety generally.Currently, there is no requirement for tyre fitters to show labels at the point of purchase so motorists are oblivious to the pros and cons of the tyres they are buying.As a result few motorists are shown the labels when buying tyres, leaving them completely in the dark about the three ratings of fuel efficiency, wet grip and passing noise.Updating the regulations should fix this by making it mandatory for tyre labels to be shown to motorists in all situations.&ldquoInformation on tyres&rsquo snow and ice performance is going to be included which will be very beneficial.The labels are also being future-proofed as the amended regulations allow for the addition of other useful information such as ratings for mileage, wear and a potential indication for re-treaded tyres.                Bulgarian jailed for Ayrshire crash that killed pensioner                British motorist lands &pound36,000 in speeding fines in just FOUR hours...The International Tyre Manufacturers' Association has also backed the proposals.In a statement to the EU earlier this year, the association's president Alfred Graham said: &ldquoITMA is fully supportive of any measure that improves tyre safety, an objective the introduction the tyre-labelling regulation sought to achieve.If that means more can be done to increase motorists&rsquo awareness and understanding of the information on the labels, ITMA will gladly play its part.A critical element of the scheme was to inform consumers of the relative value and environmental benefits of the tyres they are considering buying, so they might be able to make an informed purchasing decision.Achieving that is essential if further performance ratings are to be added to the labelling, a proposal which ITMA also believes has merit, especially for winter and re-tread tyres.Fundamentally, of course, the accurate and consistent assessment of tyre performance is critical and to the benefit of all parties.Should viable means to enhancing existing practises be found, ITMA would once again be supportive of such changes.

title: supervolcano map yellowstone long valley caldera lake toba taupo campi flegri
story: They have wiped out swathes of life before and there is a serious possibility they will do so again in the future.A supervolcano by definition is one which has had an eruption of magnitude 8 &ndash the highest and most violent possible - on the Volcano Explosivity Index in the past.The US is a hotspot for supervolanoes, with four currently located in the North American country, while Europe only has the one &ndash but it is one which could destroy the continent.Experts once predicted super-eruptions come around once every 45,000-714,000 years.                California super volcano found with 240 CUBIC MILES of magma                Yellowstone volcano gas WARNING: USGS warns of poisonous gasHowever new findings suggest they could happen as frequently as once every 5,200 years while the most likely time between super-eruptions is now thought to be around 17,000 years.Here are a list of some of the supervolcanoes which could devastate humanity.Supervolcanoes MAPPED: Where the world&rsquos biggest volcanoes are which could end all life (Image: )A map of supervolcanoes (Image: )Yellowstone volcano (Image: )Yellowstone CalderaYellowstone, located in Wyoming, USA, is the most famous supervolcano and also has the potential to be the most powerful.The Yellowstone Caldera supervolcano last erupted 700,000 years ago but experts say it should blow every one million years or so.If the powerful volcano were to erupt an estimated 87,000 people would be killed immediately and two-thirds of the USA would immediately be made uninhabitable.The thousands of tons of ash spewed into the atmosphere would block out sunlight and directly affect life beneath it creating a &ldquonuclear winter.Massive amounts of sulphur dioxide thrown into the atmosphere will form a sulphur aerosol that reflects and absorbs sunlight.Long Valley Caldera (Image: )Long Valley CalderaThe Long Valley Caldera is another supervolcano located in the US.The Californian volcano has so much magma beneath the surface, it could support an eruption equivalent to the massive one which occurred 767,000 years ago, which released 140 cubic miles of material into the atmosphere.By comparison, the 1980 Mount St Helens eruption resulted in the release of 0.29 cubic miles.The Long Valley Caldera is one of the Earth's largest calderas, measuring about 20 miles long, 11 miles wide and up to 3,000 feet (910 m) deep.During the last 5,000 years, an eruption has occurred somewhere along this chain every 250 to 700 years &ndash but usually only small ones to relieve the build-up of pressure beneath the surface.Campi Flegrei (Image: )Campi FlegreiAlso known as the Phlegraean Fields, Campi Flegrei is Europe&rsquos only supervolcano, located beneath Naples, Italy.Its formation some 39,000 years ago saw lava and rocks thrown hundreds of kilometres away in what was the most violent eruption in the past 200,000 years in Europe.It is the most densely populated volcanic region in the world, with three million people living in the nearby city of Naples.Scientists noticed that pressure was building at Campi Flegrei in 2005 and in 2012 they raised the alert level from Green to Yellow &ndash prompting stricter monitoring at the site.The ancient volcano last erupted in 1538 although it was only minor, lasting for eight days.Lake Toba (Image: )Lake TobaLake Toba is one of the world&rsquos biggest supervolcanoes and is located in Sumatra, Indonesia.It last erupted 74,000 years ago saw 2,800 cubic km of material ejected into the atmosphere.Following the eruption, global temperatures plummeted for a decade, covering huge areas of Indonesia and India in ash.An island in the middle of Lake Toba, Indonesia, is slowly rising and is thought to be a sign the Earth is bulging due to magma pressure below the surface.Taupo (Image: )TaupoA supervolcano located beneath the surface of Lake Taupo in the middle of New Zealand&rsquos North Island.It first began erupting around 300,000 years ago and has rarely been quiet since.Taupo is responsible for the most recent supervolcao eruption when it burst into life around 26,500 years ago, shoving 1200 cubic km of pumice and ash into the atmosphere.Since then, there have been 28 smaller eruptions, separated in time by between 50 and 5000 years showing just how unpredictable this one can be.

title: Brexit news Guy Verhofstadt EU citizen Settled Status UK Home Office plan alphabetical
story: Guy Verhofstadt brands UK plan to register EU citizens alphabetically 'budget airline' standard  (Image: )Responding to reports, the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit negotiator suggested Westminster should work on a better solution and &ldquonot one that a budget airline would be proud of.The Home Office may have to register up to 3.6 million EU citizens for &ldquosettled status before Britain quits the EU on March 29 2019.Despite the system being due for a &ldquophased rollout toward the end of 2018, Home Office officials are still pondering how would be most efficient and politically acceptable to carry out the Brexit promise to respect the EU citizens wanting to remain in Britain.A number of methods are being considered, including registering EU applicants sector by sector or by geographical region. However, both plans risk backlash from those left at the back of the queue, which will feature at least three million names.Home Office officials believe registering EU citizens alphabetically could be the least politically sensitive out of the three proposals put forward, according to Business Insider.According to the plans, caseworkers would process applicants in &ldquobite-sized chunks in alphabetical order based on the first letter of their name.Mr Verhofstadt, chairman of the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit Steering Group, believes Britain&rsquos plan only creates further uncertainty for EU citizens.He said: &ldquoReports that the UK Home Office is considering registering EU citizen's alphabetically are deeply troubling.                Hunt tells EU countries not to follow UK who face 'difficult period'                Varadkar's EU spokesman warns no-deal will plunge UK into CHAOS&ldquoClearly, this would create confusion and add to uncertainty.&ldquoWe need a simple, efficient and fair process, not one that a budget airline would be proud of.The influential Belgian MEP&rsquos Steering Group also issued a statement urging Britain to reconsider the plans.It reads: &ldquoWe believe such an approach would be complicated, arbitrary and could create unnecessary confusion and uncertainty for millions of EU citizens already living in limbo.Guy Verhofstadt and Home Secretary Sajid Javid have been negotiating the UK's registration system (Image: )&ldquoThose at the end of the alphabet may not get their status confirmed until the end of 2020 or later, which would be intolerable and contrary to the spirit of the assurances we have previously received.We repeat our belief that the U.K.'s registration scheme must be simple, fair, user-friendly, free and provide certainty for EU citizens.The EU Parliament's Brexit committee has also urged EU countries to offer more certainty to Britons hoping to remain on the Continent after March 2019.

title: Brexit news update EU UK MI6 bug Chequers deal Theresa May
story: Speaking on Sky News, the former Trade and Industry Secretary claimed he was not surprised to hear Brussels is worried the UK has been trying to hack its Brexit documents following reports coming from a&nbsptop European source.&nbspThe Conservative peer argued it should be naturally assumed both sides are trying to obtain information from the other side on internal conversations about the Brexit negotiations.&nbspHe revealed his mobile phone was coded by British secret services when he was a minister to prevent French secret services bugging his phone while he was there on holiday.He said: &ldquoI think we should assume both sides will try and bug the other side.                Is MI6 BUGGING the Brexit talks? EU officials raise concerns                 Brexit news: EU kept Chequers demolition documents SECRET to save May&ldquoCertainly, when I was Trade and Industry Minister British security services installed coding equipment on my phone here in France, so that if I was over here they assumed it would be bugged by the French - maybe it wasn&rsquot, maybe it was - but they wanted my conversations to be secure if I was phoning back to Downing Street or Whitehall.&ldquoAs I said, we should probably assume that the secret services of both sides are trying to hack.&ldquoIn this case I think it&rsquos overwhelmingly likely that the information which apparently reached the British Government came from a leak from someone within the EU who thought we ought to know about it.&ldquoAnd indeed the whole Cabinet ought to know about it.Brexit news: Lord Lilley claims UK should assume EU is trying to hack its documents (Image: SKY&bull)&ldquoThe real scandal is not in the question whether or not there was any bugging, but why the Cabinet, when it was assembled at Chequers, wasn&rsquot told about this reaction by the EU to the proposals which they were being asked to consider.Lord Lilley's comments come as a top European source told The Daily  that the EU&rsquos Brexit negotiating team fear they are being bugged, with the UK team getting hold of secret files &ldquowithin hours of them being presented to EU officials.According to the source, concerns were raised at a meeting of the European Council, which includes the leaders of all EU member states as well as top Brussels officials, on July 12.Sabine Wayard, the European Commission&rsquos Deputy Chief Negotiator, reportedly told the meeting that &ldquoit could not be excluded that their meetings were being bugged by the Brits.European fears developed after the UK team got told of a secret presentation shortly after it was distributed on July 5.This came at a politically explosive time, taking place just one day before Theresa May&rsquos contentious Chequers Cabinet meeting during which the UK&rsquos proposed Brexit position was agreed.The European Commission documents are believed to have been kept top secret because they threatened to dismantle Theresa May&rsquos controversial Chequers plan before its release and risk toppling her fragile minority government in Westminster.However according to the allegations within hours the UK team had got hold of the documents, and lobbied at the &ldquohighest level to prevent their publication.The slides were not formally circulated to the other 27 EU member states, according to the Daily  report.The European Commission declined to comment.

We are leaving and I think the prospects are remarkable. We are a global trading nation and I think we have got to make the most of that.When asked if the markets will be impacted by the type of deal Britain has, Mr Duncan Smith said: &ldquoYes but it is also about the EU being sensible and not putting politics in the way of what is a reasonable and frictionless deal. story: John Swinney was under fire over the current crisis with Scottish education  (Image: )Mr Swinney was also challenged over his ability to tackle the situation as radio phone-in callers lambasted a string of failures.The gruelling broadcast followed the threat of a mass boycott over the SNP&rsquos controversial primary one tests.His government&rsquos record came under further attack this week after it emerged more than 200 schools have vacancies for teachers and classroom support staff as pupils return from the summer holiday.Mr Swinney is already facing a possible national teachers&rsquo strike in the autumn in a separate dispute over pay.                SNP told to AXE school tests for FIVE-YEAR-OLDSThe Cabinet minister has said he will review how the tests are delivered to the youngest children has but ruled out scrapping them.Today he conceded there were &ldquomixed opinions about the new standardised assessments but argued they help schools quickly identify &ldquoweaknesses and challenges.Mr Swinney also insisted Scotland there is no &ldquocrisis in morale as he appeared on the BBC Radio Scotland phone-in with Stephen Jardine.But he did concede there were &ldquochallenges in the profession as he was grilled by one retiring professional.The woman, identified as Susan, said she had been a teacher for 39 years, 21 of them as a head teacher.There was a threat of a mass boycott of SNP primary tests (Image: )She told Mr Swinney his government&rsquos reforms were &ldquonot addressing the workload pressures teachers are under.She said the working-time agreement was &ldquoalmost a joke, and said &ldquothere&rsquos no way teachers can do their work in the contracted hours.Susan added: &ldquoThe number of teachers who are leaving - haemorrhaging out of the profession - I would like to know how many probationer teachers carry on and how many years they go into the profession.&ldquoYou have a real crisis in recruitment and retention and I don&rsquot hear anything there that you&rsquove said this morning that would convince me that you have got a handle on this.Mr Swinney said he accepted that &ldquoteaching life is a very busy and demanding life, but said he had engaged with teachers and professional groups to improve matters.He pointed to measures, including bursaries, to attract new teachers, adding: &ldquoI don&rsquot think we have a crisis in morale.&ldquoOf course there will be tough bits in all these discussions, but there are great bits as well.&ldquoThere are tough challenges, but also a lot of things to celebrate in Scottish education.                Sturgeon REFUSES to climbdown on state  scheme                 SNP accused of blocking Prince Charles papers in secrecy rowBut Susan said: &ldquoI just feel it&rsquos &lsquocrisis, what crisis&rsquo, and he&rsquos not listening at all.Lesley, a grandmother from the Borders, told Mr Swinney that pupils were let down by a lack of teachers, and a failing exam system.She said: &ldquoI don&rsquot think the system is working and it is punishing children very badly.&ldquoIt is robbing them of their confidence, it is robbing them of their ability and it is robbing them of what should be a good life for them.One parent, who was not named, asked Mr Swinney what he planned to do about the ongoing recruitment crisis in schools.She claimed that her children&rsquos school had been &ldquodown a chemistry teacher for five years and said her son &ldquowas taught physics last year by a man who could barely read or write English in North Lanarkshire.Following the broadcast Scottish Labour&rsquos education spokesman Iain Gray said: &ldquoJohn Swinney shows no sign of listening to parents or teachers.&ldquoThe message was loud and clear that he should drop his testing of four and five year olds in P1, and if he wants to fix the teacher recruitment crisis he has to do something about teachers&rsquo pay and workload.Mr Swinney has come under increasing pressure to scrap testing for the youngest pupils after campaign group Upstart Scotland urged parents to withdraw their children.The Lib Dems have also claimed that the Scottish Government deceived parents about their right to withdraw their children if they choose.The government insists parents have &ldquono statutory right of opt out, but schools have &ldquodiscretion to decide whether pupils should take part.

title: Weather forecast UK Met Office latest heatwave hot weather august 2018 weekend
story: Freakishly hot weather could hold out through September and possibly into October, according to some long-range forecasters.A plume of warm, sultry air will sweep into Britain during the middle of next week just as the nation starts to cool down.Temperatures could reach their highest so far this summer with the 38.5C (101.3F) record still under threat, experts say.Only Scotland and parts of northern England will escape the sweltering steam-bath although it will be warmer than average across much of the UK.                UK HOT weather forecast: Britain faces 43C temp as HOTTEST spell hits                UK weather forecast: Britain braces for CONTINENTAL SCORCHERJames Madden, forecaster for Exacta Weather, warned Britain could be facing another lengthy heatwave.He said: &ldquoOur models show we are about to go into another period of prolonged summery weather, there is a growing likelihood we could see another extreme heat surge during the second half of this month.&ldquoIt is not out of the question that Britain will bask in some of the highest temperatures of summer to date, even beating those seen over the past two months.&ldquoThere is every chance this summer will come in as the hottest on record as temperatures rise back into the mid 30Cs at the very least.&ldquoLonger-range projections show the possibility of warm weather continuing into the start of the meteorological autumn and even into October.Britons have been urged to make the most of a brief cooler spell which will bring a drop in temperatures over the next couple of days.UK weather forecast: Britain is set to sizzle as the UK heatwave returns (Image: NETWEATHER)Torrential rain will hammer swathes of the country as a cold front moves in from the Atlantic on Wednesday night.Northern Britain will be first in the firing line before downpours pelt the south and southeast on Thursday morning.The rain will clear through the day making way for much fresher air to bring temperatures down widely, the Met Office said.Meteorologist Bonnie Diamond said: &ldquoQuite an active front will move over Wales and northern England on Wednesday evening bringing some heavy rain.&ldquoThis will move into the southeast of the country through Thursday morning and it will be a much fresher day with maximum temperatures of around 21C (69.8F).&ldquoFriday is looking more unsettled in the north again with a drier, nicer day forecast elsewhere although it will still feel fresher compared to the start of the week.                BBC weather forecast: Temperatures to SOAR &ndash but not before a storm                Four more years of heatwaves on wayUK weather forecast: Temperatures are set to soar back to 30C this week (Image: NETWEATHER)Rain will continue to pelt Scotland and northwestern England over the weekend with sunshine confined to the south, she said.South-eastern England will hold on to the fine weather into next week as temperatures start to head upwards, she added.She said: &ldquoFrom the middle of next week onwards there will be a good deal of dry, bright weather in the southeast as a result this part of the country will be back to warm or very warm temperatures.&ldquoIt is also going to be humid as tropical air moves into southern Britain, later next week we are expecting temperatures in the high 20Cs.&ldquoThe longer-range outlook shows there is a possibility of the warm or very warm weather lasting in the southeast, it will be more unsettled in northern parts of the country.Warm weather will hold out at least until the end of the month meaning Britons will enjoy another bank holiday scorcher.

story: Around 11pm local time last night, Tropical Storm Lane was located about 1,390 miles southwest of the southern tip of Baja California, Mexico.The storm is moving west about 12mph and while still 2,100 miles away from Hilo, Hawaiians are keeping a close eye on forecasts.Last night, the storm had maximum sustained winds of 50mph which are expected to continue strengthening.The Weather Channel forecast said by Saturday &ldquowe could be looking at a category three hurricane.                North Sea HURRICANE: Huge 95mph gales and TORNADOES to batter TOMORROW                Japan weather: Tropical storm Leepi to SMASH southern Japan on Tues...The current track shows Lane due to pass to the south of Hawaii but as these types of storms have shown, they are subject to change at short notice.By Sunday morning, winds could be up to 120mph,&nbsphowever&nbspthe worst of it should occur when Lane is over the open ocean.If the storm stays on track, there is still a chance the edges will knick Hawaii,&nbspan could&nbspbring big swell and heavy rain.Derek Wroe,&nbsplead&nbspforecaster with the National Weather Service in Honolulu, said: &ldquoWarm ocean water is the fuel for hurricanes.Tropical Storm Lane: By Sunday morning, winds could be up to 120mph (Image: The Weather Channel )Tropical Storm Lane: The current track shows Lane due to pass to the south of Hawaii (Image: The Weather Channel )He added: &ldquoExpect intensification at least into the weekend. By midday Saturday, it should be approximately 1,000 miles southeast of the Big Island.National forecasters said Lane &ldquoseems destined to become a major hurricane like Hector, which passed safely south of Hawaii last week.But forecasters are urging Hawaii residents to watch Lane closely in case of any changes in track.While Hawaii braces itself for hurricane season, it is also battling another natural event: the ongoing eruption of Kilauea volcano.                Hurricane Hector latest: Storm MISSES Hawaii - where will it land?                Foreign Aid budget WILL be used for disaster hit UK territories Tropical Storm Lane: Lane is forecast to strengthen into a hurricane (Image: Getty )Kilauea on Hawaii&rsquos Big Island has been erupting since May 3, sending huge volumes of lava, ash and gas across the island into the atmosphere.The map of the&nbspisland island&nbsphas been totally&nbsprebuild&nbspby the eruption, which has seen vast rivers of lava our across the island and build up a previous bay.Thousands of residents have been displaced and about 700 homes destroyed as the mighty volcano shows its power.Finally, activity seemed to be slowing, as Hawaii Civil Defense has said that activity at the summit of Kilauea has reduced, with fewer earthquakes.The most active of the erupting fissures, Fissure 8, is now &ldquomostly crusted over, according to the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory.However, civil defence warned: &ldquoAlthough a lull in activity continues, it is common for eruptions to go through periods of diminished output, or to pause completely, only to reactivate days or weeks later, or longer.&ldquoActivity could occur at any time. Residents should remain informed and heed Hawaii County Civil Defense messages and warnings.A hurricane has never been recorded striking an active volcano, and results of such an event are unknown.

story: The study, written by Dr Robert Hanck&eacute of the London School of Economics in partnership with derivatives trading company IG, looked at what would happen were Germany to decide to quit the single European currency and go it alone one more &ndash with potentially dire economic consequences.It states: &ldquoAs the strongest economy in the eurozone, Germany is the only country that can credibly leave the euro.&ldquoSome German citizens and politicians see themselves as 'victims&rsquo of the euro, feeling that it forces them to prop up countries with weaker economies.&ldquoIf that feeling grows, a majority of citizens could vote in favour of a new deutschmark if given the choice.                Economist warns Macron's plan last chance to save 'unsustainable' EU                Germany MUST pay for Brexit EU budget shortfall, claims expertThe research points out that Germany is the &ldquoeconomically dominant country in the euro area, accounting for&nbsproughly 27 percent of the eurozone&rsquos total GDP.In addition, it has a general government budget surplus of approximately 1.5 million.The report suggestions that a move to create a new German national currency would have &ldquodramatic regional consequences and would very likely to opposed by other 18 member-states of the EU who have adopted the euro as their currency.The report suggests: &ldquoGermany&rsquos departure from the eurozone would likely lead to the collapse of the currency and conceivably even the European Union as a whole.The eurozone would be threatened by a relaunched Deutschmark (Image: )A total of 19 countries are in the euro area (Image: Wikipedia)Most of the northern economies would probably turn their backs on economic and monetary union to join a new deutchsmark bloc, the report argues.The euro&rsquos collapse would have a serious impact on the political consensus which has dominated Europe since World War 2.Neither would Germany be immune from the fallout, because the launch of a new deutschmark, which would attract huge levels of investment with the result that other currencies operating in the now likely defunct eurozone would be depreciated.As a result, this could have a knock-on effect on Germany&rsquos exports, triggering a deep economic recession in the country similar to that witnessed in the early 1990s.                Pound to euro exchange rate: Sterling &lsquounlikely to recover losses&rsquo                 'EU is TERRIFIED' Italy says Brussels RUNNING SCARED of populist up...Emmanuel Macron, pictured with Germany chancellor Angela Merkel, wants eurozone reform (Image: )Dr Hanck&eacute, Associate Professor of Political Economy at the LSE said: &ldquoThe political will among European elites to keep the euro intact is, as we have seen since the Greek bailouts, very strong.&ldquoStrong enough to bear the costs of the single currency &ndash unless, that is, German voters and politicians begin to perceive these costs to be too lopsided.The warnings come on the same day Italian economist Ilaira Bifarini told Express French President Emmanuel Macron&rsquos plan to increase EU integration might be the bloc&rsquos only chance.He said: &ldquoMacron&rsquos plan is the only solution for the European monetary union and the European Union as a whole to survive.&ldquoWe&rsquore facing a crossroads.&ldquoThe EU can either go towards more integration, more risk sharing, and also towards more cohesion of economic policies and not only those monetary, or there can&rsquot be anything other than an implosion of the euro system &ndash which is proving to be no longer sustainable.&ldquoSo the options are two. More integration or a breakup.Mr Macron wants to create a stand-alone eurozone budget and a new EU finance minister with the aim of strengthening economic and monetary union.For more details of various currency scenarios, click here

title: whale massacre sandav gur v gar island faroe islands annual hunt cull whale driving
story: The sea off the village of Sandav&aacutegur turns red (Image: TRIANGLE)The sea off the coast of V&aacutegar island in the Faroes was turned red with blood as the massacre unfolded.The practice, known as whale driving, saw children as young as five take part in the hunt of 180 whales in the village of Sandav&aacutegur.Every summer, hundreds of pilot and beaked whales are killed across the Faroe Islands, a Danish archipelago located hundreds of miles off the Scottish coast between Norway and Iceland.Whale driving on the Faroe Islands dates back to the late 16th century and involve residents herding pods of whales into shallow waters.                Blue whale SLAUGHTERED by Icelandic hunters                 Whale and dolphin SLAUGHTER: 100,000 creatures 'being blown up'They are then killed using a spinal lance that is thrust into the animal's neck to break its spinal cord.While locals have been carrying out the annual hunts ahead of the sparse winter months for centuries, the practice appears shocking and gruesome to outsiders.Cambridge University student Alastair Ward, 22, was visiting the archipelago to celebrate his graduation when he and a friend stumbled across the bloodshed.He said: &ldquoWe were walking round this bay when this family of locals ran over and said 'you're lucky, there's a whale coming'.The whale massacre takes place every summer (Image: TRIANGLE)Local official insist the cull is sustainable despite its gruesome nature (Image: TRIANGLE)&ldquoWe thought it would just be one being dragged in but more and more boats kept appearing on the horizon.&ldquoI couldn't believe how many whales there were. They were driving them into the bay, prodding them with their oars.&ldquoOnce they got close enough, the whole town sprinted in and started hacking at them.&ldquoEven the children were getting involved, pulling on the ropes and jumping on the carcasses.                Iceland whale SLAUGHTER: Fury as new hunting season comes to Iceland                Outrage as Japan harpoons 122 pregnant whales in the name of science&ldquoWe just sat there speechless and a bit upset but you couldn't really pull yourself away.&ldquoThe squealing from the whales was horrible.&ldquoThey were putting hooks on ropes in their blowholes to pull them in and then hacking at them with knives. They didn't die in a very humane way.&ldquoA lot of the locals were all saying how it's the same as farming but I couldn't really agree with that.Villagers attack a whale with a spinal lance (Image: TRIANGLE)The slaughter of whales  off the coast of V&aacutegar island in the Faroes gets under way (Image: TRIANGLE)&ldquoChildren were jumping on top of them. They just have such a different attitude to us because they're brought up on it.The hunt has been criticised in the past by animal rights campaigners who say the ritual is cruel and unnecessary.But local officials insist the hunt is sustainable and ensures the islands, which have limited opportunities for farming, are as self-sufficient as possible.The say each whale provides several hundreds of kilos of meat and blubber, food which would otherwise have to be imported from abroad to the islands at a cost to the locals and the environment.

title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. Picture research: Alfie SnellingTHIS Morning, Wednesday:Gok Wan: “Coming up, Ninja nanas, in a minute, John Torode’s in the Lake District at 11.45, and we’ve got the return of the Hawaiian shirt at midday.“First, would you like to live ten years longer?”Ten years? Right now I’m ambivalent abOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn is unfit to be labour leader
story: His entire political career has been spent in close company with anti- Semites, terrorist sympathisers and extremists.So it shouldn’t be a surprise that he was pictured appearing to pay his respects to Black September, the terror group which murdered 11 Israelis and one German policeman at the Munich Olympics.That’s a group that not only killed in cold blood but tortured and brutalised their victims too.It is genuinely shocking that the Leader of the Opposition is so willing to lie about it. To say that he was “present but not involved” is an insult to voters’ intelligence when photographs show him holding a wreath and gurning for a nearby camera.To allow his press office to say the widows of those murdered in Munich were being “misled” is, even among the many shameful episodes we’ve seen since he became Labour leader three hate-filled years ago, disgraceful.The most vital qualification for power in this country must be integrity. And Jeremy Corbyn has demonstrated this week that he has absolutely none of it.But for all of the shame that he brings upon Labour, it is nothing compared to the spinelessness of the party’s “moderate” MPs whose opposition to Corbyn extends not much further than wishy-washy tweets.“Present but not involved” isn’t an excuse for Corbyn but nor is it for the cowards on Labour’s backbenches.Corbyn cannot be allowed near government. But the rest of the party has lost the public’s faith too.TOMORROW, official figures are likely to suggest that train fares will go up by another 3.5 per cent in January.If you’re a commuter who has put up with delayed and cancelled trains, you’ll be wondering what you’re paying for.After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rid harry and meghan turbulent
story: Most of the time, they make the Windsors seem a happy and (almost) normal bunch — no small feat.So why oh why is the Palace spin machine making such a spectacular mess with the Markles?Anybody with half a brain could tell, from the moment Prince Harry and Meghan started dating, that her family could turn into a royal pain in the neck.You’ve got a vengeful and jealous half-sister Samantha, who despises Meghan and has been briefing against her for more than a year.She is now telling hacks that she knows Harry and Meghan’s marriage won’t last, which is charming.Then you’ve got Thomas Markle, the dad, an eccentric character who is furious at being “locked out” of his daughter’s life.Barely a day goes by without Mr Markle hurling another negative headline across the Atlantic in the direction of his new son-in-law.Mr Markle insists that, contrary to official briefings, the rift between him and his daughter continues. He says he was told that he couldn’t speak at the wedding and that Harry berated him on the phone for mishandling the Press while he was recovering from a heart attack.The official royal response to these outbursts has been, effectively, to shove their fingers in their ears and shout la-la-la (or lah-lah-lah).The snobby courtiers and hangers-on dismiss Markle père as fame-hungry.That’s not altogether wrong — he is clearly desperate, as he proved by posing for snaps with the paparazzi in the run-up to the wedding.But it’s not good enough to wish he’d just go away.Meghan is now one of the most photographed and sought-after women in the world. Her very well-paid PR flunkies should have seen these familial landmines a mile off and defused them.But they have failed.Thomas Markle is a difficult and proud man, no doubt. But that is why he should have been treated with care, not frozen out.Why did Team Windsor not find him a role and approach him long before the wedding to make sure he didn’t feel excluded.It’s hard not to feel for him.His ex, Meghan’s mother Doria, was hailed as one of the stars of the wedding.Because she’s a black woman, she invited lots of gushing commentary about the monarchy becoming more diverse and modern.Amen to that. But poor old podgy Thomas, an awkward-looking white bloke, has been shunned from his daughter’s nuptials. You can’t blame him for speaking out.The royal courtiers enjoy the adulation the monarchy receives because Prince Harry has been “brave” enough to marry a woman with a complicated background.But the Palace spin machine freaks out when it comes to confronting the reality of Meghan’s parentage.Perhaps they just find it too vulgar.Harry’s PR man is Jason Knauf, an American specialist in “crisis management” having worked for Royal Bank of Scotland. He excels at sending angry letters to journalists he feels have gone too far snooping into Harry and Meghan’s private lives.But he doesn’t seem to have a clue as to how to handle his clients’ grumpy relatives.As a result, the monarchy is facing arguably its worst crisis since the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.We are often told how brilliant the Royal Family’s PR is. Part of the new royal spin, in fact, is about how great the royals now are at spin. They have “rebranded” the monarchy for the 21st century, and so on.Look at the blizzard of positive guff accompanying Prince William, Kate, and Harry’s campaign for mental illness last year.They were, it was said, making the younger Windsors seem more touchy-feely.At the moment, however, they don’t seem sensitive enough to speak to Meghan’s suffering in-laws.That’s not what you’d call a good look.The truth is, royal press officers have long got too much credit.The British admire the Queen because she is admirable.Overall, we prefer monarchy to any other system of government. That’s just common sense. It’s nothing to do with any ingenious branding and media strategy.The public also feels that the younger royals deserve a chance.At a time when our country is consumed by Brexit and political arguments, the wedding of Harry and Meghan came as a blessed relief — something we could all celebrate.The couple both came from broken homes, and nobody cared so long as they were happy. That’s all great.   But it’s obvious that Meghan has, as one royal expert put it, “background baggage that needs unpacking”.Insiders now say the treatment of the Markle family has been a “shambles”.This is before we consider the potential PR bombshells that could erupt if and when Meghan’s ex-husband, Trevor Engelson, decides to grant some interviews.The British don’t want to see the monarchy turned into a reality TV soap, as the Markles and Windsors wage a media war with each other.It’s trashy and embarrassing.But unless the Palace can tackle Meghan’s disgruntled kin, that’s exactly what is happening.Maybe we need a changing of the royal PR guard — before it’s too late.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour mp refuses six times to say jeremy corbyn is fit to be pm and hints he could be ousted as leader next month
story: Madeleine Moon failed six times when asked to say if the Labour leader was fit to become Prime Minister.She blasted him for dominating newspaper headlines with negative coverage over his controversial trip to Tunisia in 2014.He has admitted he laid a wreath to honour members of the Black September terrorists who killed 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich 1972 - but refused to apologise to the widows for attending.After pictures emerged of him at the ceremony at a cemetery in Tunis, Mr Corbyn initially denied he was involved - saying he was marking the deaths of 47 people in Israeli airstrikes in 1985.But he has since changed his story several times, and now faces a House of Commons probe over failing to properly declare the trip to the authorities.The Labour boss has come under increasing pressure this week, which comes on the back of the partys ongoing anti-Semitism crisis.And today Ms Moon, the MP for Bridgend, hinted that Mr Corbyn could face moves to oust him as early as Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool next month.She told TalkRadio: “Individuals as leaders come and go. And the party will look at this I am sure extremely forcefully at the next conference.Lets wait and see what conference decides.“Theres always a rule in politics: if youre on the front pages for too long you become the story and thats not good because you miss all the good and effective things that the Labour Party is doing in terms of policy and holding this government to account.”Host Julia Hartley-Brewer asked her: “Do you think that a man who lays wreaths at the tombs of terrorists who have killed innocent people is fit to be the British Prime Minister?”But Ms Moon would only reply: “That will be a decision for the British people.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
